comments.commentBody: You should read Barbara Ehrenreich's book "Bait and Switch."   Networking is great -- if you're already employed.  If you're unemployed in a deep recession, not so much.   And not everyone has personal networks where they can call up their country club pals and get a job referral.

36% of recent college graduates are either unemployed or ar working at a job that does not require a college degree. They can't all be history majors.

http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2014/02/20/recent-college-graduates-face-rou...

Whether or not it's accurate to say that the economy writ large faces a skills gap, too many individuals--the 11 million unemployed, the millions more not actively looking for work but counted in the U6 measure, and (most alarmingly) some enormous number in the later stages of transition from education to the labor market--sure do.

Dr. Krugman glances off perhaps the most relevant fact, which is that better educated individuals achieve stronger labor market outcomes. Yes, this has always been true... but the relationship (as I'm certain he knows) is far stronger today than it was fifty or even twenty years ago. For college graduates in the knowledge economy, we're always pretty much at full employment; high school dropouts face a permanent Great Depression.

That's the long-term answer--not one likely to win elections or even drive page views, but the only really good fix.

In the meantime, while we're building human capital we need to better leverage social capital. Personal and professional networks are often the determinant of whether or not unemployed workers quickly land a new job. I wish the researchers would focus a bit more in that direction.

So then you have no right to complain when people educing a cold winter with lots of snow say global warming is a hoax, or a cold spring...

Weather is not the same as climate. Drought is something that happens over many years, it is not by itself an indicator of anything just as a cold winter does not mean there is no global warming.
Ironically the earth warming means much greater crop yields, which can continue to sustain a growing world population.

My estimate is that the human population will be rather quickly reduced to approximately what it was in pre-industrial times:  about one billion  human beings.  The sooner this happens, the better. We are a cancer on the face of this beautiful, precious planet.

Well put. Going hungry is more complex than solving climate change. It is about family planning, birth control, educating women and thinking globally about the consequences of actions, including restraint. Yet these never topics for discussion. Instead the arguments on global hunger are focused on simply giving money to often corrupt regimes, churches send missionaries to convert persons to prevent god's wrath and punishment while encouraging irresponsible reproduction, and unrestricted GMO use?

We may have gone past the limit of the number of people that the earth can sustain. With the entire planet's food production machinery operating at max capacity, we can barely feed our inhabitants now. Climate change has thrown a wrench into that machine.

In 1960, there were 3 billion people on the planet. Today there are 7 billion, more than double. Now consider that the major food producers had decent weather over that period. Much land is either drying up now, or flooding out. Technology has increased crop yields but that doesn't matter if there is no rain, nothing grows.

The naysayers will not be convinced even if their coastal town is washed away in a storm surge. They will continue to follow their beliefs with the dedication of devout theist. Facts don't matter.

The carbon producers will not be convinced either because this is how they make their money and will not accept that they are doing anything detrimental. Facts don't matter. Profits matter.

People in the poorer nations will die while we bicker over established facts. Wars will be fought over access to rivers. One billion get their drinking water from glacial melt that soon will be no more. I have no idea how much the globe's population will have to shrink to achieve sustainability, but it will shrink.

@Alan:  If we listen to you, we will spend a huge sum of money to reduce CO2 - which is NOT pollution.  We should in fact ignore CO2 and spend them money reducing REAL pollution, for far more gains and preventing real environmental disasters instead of naturally occurring changes.

Your example is apt but not for the reason you think. No one would buy seat belts if they doubled the price of the car. That is what global warming fanatics are trying to sell us.  Fortunately when it come down to actually paying for these doubtful theories they run into a brick wall politically with the public since even the most uneducated trailer park dweller understands intuitively that you hitting him up for $200 to fill up his gas tank to reduce greenhouse gasses by 2% is not going to cause the bad weather in Atlanta to go away.

For people who don't think climate change is real or that it is man made, and even if it is, nothing needs to be done because it would be, "too expensive", there is a very simple concept that even you could probably relate to:

Even if you are right and it has a low probability of occurring, it is of such a high order of catastrophic impact on the planet that even you would want to prevent it if possible.

Consider that most people have a low probability of getting into a head-on, deadly car crash, but most people wear seat belts now even if not legally mandated. It's simple, if it does happen, and you didn't have the belt on, you pay such a drastic price: your life.

But let's let our children worry about the problem for which we stick our heads in the sand: global warming.

You'd prefer to pay part of your hard earned money to the oil companies in tax subsidies so that they can continue what they do without developing alternatives, and let our national security continue to be held hostage to the bellicose dictators of oil-rich countries.

Yeah, that makes sense.

I agree that our growing population is the greatest threat to the well-being of all living creatures on this planet.

Our entire foreign policy and the lions' share of our domestic one should be devoted to just two goals: free birth control and education for all.

Thanks, Kendall.

Always good to read the unbiased analyses of Big Energy.

@unreceived dogma: to some it's like saying that the moon is made of green cheese - pure myth. We could ignore them as the tin-hat crowd, expect they influence a segment of the politicians who then gum up efforts to make meaningful policy changes.
The headline cracks me up. Isn't that a bit like saying: the sun rises in the east, sets in the west?
Didn't he say something to the effect that a capitalist would sell his own mother? Or was that Lenin?

What's wrong with wind turbines off Cape Cod (and it would be the ocean, not the bay, and it shouldn't just be Cape Cod, but the entire coast) or solar farms in deserts? Sounds like a pretty good idea to me. Go visit Europe and especially Amsterdam. There are wind turbines everywhere on the coast and it actually looks kind of nice. Would it be nicer if we didn't need them? Sure, but that's the problem. We're selfish and we refuse to make sacrifices and compromises. Instead, we choose to live in denial and blame the messenger. People even argue against forcing car manufacturers to increase gas mileage.

As far as population is concerned, birth rates in Western countries are actually quite low - below the replacement rate in many, but population growth in the third world is very high and there's little that anyone can do about it. The opposition of conservative religions to the use of birth control is an absurd policy as ever increasing populations in poor countries will lead to war and murder. These religions don't seem to have a problem with killing after a child has been born. When was the last time a major conservative religious leader spoke out against a war?

But population control can also lead to problems: modern societies need at least five working people for each retired person. Countries with low birthrates and aging populations tend not be innovative.

The real answer is investment in alternative energy infrastructure.

Over population and affluenza. And the beloved New York Times right in the middle selling a glamorous upscale lifestyle where status is achieved by conspicuous consumption. Suits and ties that we wear to Court and furs that she wears with Prada send the messages that confuses our real humble relationship with the planet. Some dystopian futures have everybody wearing the same grey hoody and eating Soylent Green. That is better than the Road with the nuclear fallout and ash clouds. If we First Worlders refuse to adapt to the new climate change reality, humanity will likely come to a global conflict and then wearing identical grey hoodies may be the new luxury. The loss of key species due to ocean acidification could provoke a crisis sooner.   We need to plan the cultural soft landing away from unrestricted consumption and vicarious comparison and to have a chance to preserve what is valuable- truth and shared freedom.

We, as a society have never, ever, done anything about a problem until it was on our doorstep.  We always kick the can down the road.  Luckily, this has always worked, more or less.  This time, I think things may be different.  Canned goods, anyone?
Maybe not the extinction of all life but we're heading for a big reset. The the process can start all over again.
